6/ To incentivize the development of more public goods, Canto proposes a new funding mechanism: contract secured revenue (CSR).

5/ These protocols charge no fees - there‚Äôs not even a swap fee on the DEX. Instead, liquidity is subsidized with the chain‚Äôs CANTO token treasury to attract LPs. This benefits users through cheaper transactions, and limits fee extraction/platform risk for devs building on top.
4/ Canto was launched with a number of core applications: fee-less, largely unchangeable DeFi protocols, referred to as FPI for Free Public Infra: a DEX, lending market, and native unit of account.
3/ Canto is running a new experiment in crypto: investing a chain‚Äôs resources in the development and maintenance of public goods, and application development more broadly.

2/ Zooming out, some of the largest communities in crypto started with small but hyper-loyal, quasi-religious followings:

Early Bitcoiners sought to create a new monetary system
The first Ethereum devs espoused the ‚Äúworld computer‚Äù vision

An implication for protocols is that they need to carefully consider how to grow integrations and competition of their complements‚Äîthe products on top, in order to achieve that more normal distribution.

I've written more about that here: https://t.co/No4b8fShPZ

If there is a more competition, resulting in a more normal distribution of products on top of the protocol, its more likely Mr. Market tells you the rational thing to do is keep building on top of the protocol--and even pay its fees (assuming they're minimally extractive)
If you are a power-law winning product that makes up a majority of the userbase of a protocol, Mr. Market likely  tells you not to share the value your company is creating with the DAO.

That same logic can be applied to companies building on top of protocols

Even if you value decentralization, you may need to make the difficult decision to contradict Mr. Market each time you allows fees to flow from your users to the DAO (as opposed to the company)
Even collectors who value the idea of creator royalties have to make the difficult decision to contradict Mr. Market each and every time they choose to honor them.

Interesting to juxtapose the debate on creator royalties with the coming struggle of web3 product teams vs. protocol DAOs they build on top of.

If efficient markets eliminate creator royalties, what will they do to DAOs over time?

Conflating consumer surplus and ownership is a category error; user-owned platforms can/do employee the same growth tactics of deferred monetization to yield consumer surplus (e.g. Uniswap's fee switch); that choice has little/nothing to do with ownership.
Next, argues products already provide early users value in the form of consumer surplus (described as deferred monetization) and argues this is a form of "ownership economy."

Most definitely can also be true, often the case, but this line of thinking doesn't account for new products where ownership *is* the product, or a keystone of the user experience. NFTs are a good example. Users can come to see ownership as fundamental.
It goes on to argue that turning users into investors creates cognitive overhead; friction that can detract from user adoption.

This definitely can be true, but its not always. Especially for products in fragmented markets whose early users build a critical mass of supply, ownership (distributed via airdrops or inflationary rewards) can be lower cost activation than cash/in-kind alternatives.
First, views equity as part of the cost structure of a product, and assumes this cost structure will always be more expensive than products that are not user-owned.

Rather, protocols should simply seek to drive integrations that result in stronger network effects. If this can be done, both protocols and the products on top can likely step into the flow of value.
So to revisit last years Products vs. Protocols piece: I‚Äôd de-emphasize the idea that protocols should seek to commoditize their complements.
A protocol can provide the best pricing, or be the most trusted to be routed to because of liquidity, risk management, or lindy‚Äîall forms of switching costs which can likely be extracted.
For instance, a great product might provide the best user interface, or the most (price) efficient routing to get their job done.
For that to be true, products and protocol need to specialize in different areas of value creation.

I‚Äôve come around to the view that this is a myopic framing. Great products expand the addressable market for protocols, and so long as there‚Äôs a network effect in the protocol, there‚Äôs likely a place for both to capture some value.
In my published framework of Protocols vs. Product, I framed product level fees as in direct competition with fees that protocols can charge.
What does that mean for protocols?
So for practical purposes, we should assume the default: products that people want will monetize

So while its true that earning tokens from a protocol treasury is a nice-to-have, and potentially a new source of revenue for product teams, it just doesn‚Äôt stack up to controlling your own destiny by earning cold hard fees directly from customers.
And its a stronger default than what last year‚Äôs post suggested: that product teams could forgo fees by instead earning tokens from the protocols they build on top of.
Of course, building a great business is a very strong incentive to build a product in the first place. Its the default reason most do it.
Products usually own the end user relationship. If a product is something that people want, and its in the flow of value, there‚Äôs a good chance the product can step into that flow.
Here‚Äôs an orthogonal thought that updates some of the thinking:

Last year I argued protocols that capture fees should buck against that future, and offered a strategy on how to do it:
https://t.co/Gb1y1UXegA

Will Web3 end up like traditional open source, where  (application) protocols end up as open source commodities, and products capture all the value on top?

web2: user experience (UX)
web3: owner experience (OX)

The token design space is still nascent and we‚Äôll spend the next decade refining the craft of bringing new tokens and ownership experiences to market. But the history of product design and user research provides some good lessons to draw upon. 

Put yourself in the users shoes.

Ownership through tokens is a tool to address user problems in entirely new ways. And so, when setting out to design a token its worth asking:

*What is the core user problem, and how does the token address it?*

Networks like @DIMO_Network or @usebraintrust  allow owners to capture value from their contribution to the network‚Äôs marketplace. This is ownership satisfying a need for financial security via economic alignment.
For example, projects like @nounsdao or @shibuyaxyz  allow owners to dictate the course of the project or plot. These projects are premised on ownership satisfying a need to be heard.

Ownership is a design space for new experiences that address core human needs:

The need for financial security
The need to be heard and participate
The need for social belonging and community
The need to have control over how we work
...

Executing on these questions should be grounded in an understanding of user needs. 

If great products optimize for excellent user experience (UX) in addressing these needs, great tokens should optimize for a great ownership experience (OX).

Products and tokens both require:

- Engineering: How does it operate?
- Design: How does the user navigate and experience it?
- Go-to-market: How should it be distributed?

Huge thanks to @boironattorney who poured months of sweat into this report and has been an incredible resource to @variantfund's portfolioüí™

I'm only scratching the surface on the meat in this report. If you're a founder (or lawyer) intent on making the journey of sufficient decentralization, highly recommend reading the full report/PDF: https://t.co/HdAvnZAFrP

As described, an ideal system would be split between ‚Äúsupported subDAOs‚Äù like BD and ‚Äúoperations subDAOs‚Äù for finance, legal and other services. Operations subDAOs would empower the supported subDAOs to be as independent from one another as possible.

What  most of these tactics have in common is open and transparent communication, no asymmetry. The other key element is community structure. Most web3 communities have one of the four outlined here: https://t.co/K4qdeRdmeR
Governance ‚Äì construct strong protocol governance, and distribute power to the community. (Example: Aave, Compound)

Marketing ‚Äì use bounties to incentivize growth and marketing tactics, publish marketing strategies frequently

Intellectual Property ‚Äì distribute IP to the community as much as possible. (Example: Nouns, CrypToadz)

Software development ‚Äì keep code open source and publish roadmaps, use grants and bounties, make protocol easy to integrate with others. (example: Ethereum, @uniswapgrants )

Business development ‚Äì keep biz dev members independent and well-funded. (example: 1inch)

Just as there is no single, canonical definition of sufficient decentralization, there is no single perfect way to achieve it. 

But there are some best practices. 

Some actual tactics from @boironattorney's playbook üëá

How can networks strike the right balance on efficiency and decentralizing these activities?
 
Described as a spectrum, decentralization is a composite of every action that a community takes. In that way, sufficient decentralization is not an end point, but an ongoing journey. https://t.co/NyzOmxyJak

While much has been written on the ‚Äúsufficient decentralization‚Äù of protocols themselves, Marc‚Äôs piece covers everything else around the protocols: development, BD, marketing, IP, governance, etc. Sufficient decentralization of off-chain activities. https://t.co/Iop7XLuqyc

First, some backstory. ‚ÄúSufficient decentralization‚Äù was coined by the SEC‚Äôs Williams Hinman. In 2018, he argued the Ethereum network had become sufficiently decentralized because no single, identifiable, coordinated group drove the protocol or value of ETH.

Achieving sufficient decentralization is a goal of many projects in web3, but how to do so has remained mercurial.

A protocol subsidy for product teams is about finding a cooperative equilibrium between products and protocols. 

What are the big brain takes on this?

The argument is that protocols should continually seek to commoditize their compliments (the products built on top) and distribute the value generated for the protocol, to those that drive it (the product teams)
To find the optimal balance between scaling protocol growth/value and building sustainable products, protocols have a new tool in the toolkit: tokens to subsidize product teams.

Because products create a lot of value and own the end-user relationship -- so rather than complimenting protocols as they've done to date, why shouldn't they competing by extracting their own fees (is this bad?) or even forking, vertically integrating?

Its about finding balance

However my view is this outcome is not a given. Protocol treasuries need to be governed properly to make it so.

Why is that?

In a way, this is a redux of the Fat Protocols thesis (2016) which argues that stateful protocols will capture the bulk of the value through tokens, while products will be thin, commodity layers on top.

h/t @jmonegro (OP) + @nickgrossman for pointing this out

So what was the core team's incentive to build those products and give them away for free?

An allocation of tokens, which align their incentives with that of a decentralized network of users who contribute to the protocol in other ways.

https://t.co/rXcyLURHwM
Those network effects make the protocols worth integrating with -- and today, the bulk of the activity in those protocols is driven by third-party products!

Uniswap Labs, Compound Labs, et al first built innovative protocols -- and then, were in a great position to build the best products on top (e.g. https://t.co/IrM9wf2NW9) which drove growth/network effects.

Looking to challenge my thinking on an old post: https://t.co/GCVETukRtE

In short, the argument is that protocol teams have succeeded by virtue of building & commoditizing their compliments: products built on top, which were given away for free to scale protocol growth/value.

Throughout the rest of this year, we‚Äôll be unpacking more of the key insights from this report in follow-up essays. In the meantime, check out the piece here: https://t.co/RBmatYnVfH

Best practices for designing effective token distributions are still being unearthed. This is core to the research we are doing @variantfund to accelerate projects in our portfolio and the ownership economy broadly https://t.co/l5wYegMLqn
We‚Äôve seen how distributing ownership in protocols and NFT communities can jumpstart growth, but also how sustaining that growth and fostering consistent community engagement has proven trickier

Our belief is that user-owned products and services will define the next generation of the internet, resulting in networks that grow bigger, faster, and ‚Äî if we do it right ‚Äî come with the potential to build a more equitable digital economy.

Published ~2 years ago, our thesis on the Ownership Economy predicted that crypto would cross over to mainstream audiences by making ownership a keystone of new user experiences. 

Since then: yield farming, governance, NFTs and more have brought this design space to life.

The team @variantfund spent a few months taking stock in the current state of the Ownership Economy being built in web3: https://t.co/RBmatYnVfH

Excited to see the potential of scalable, shared data legos for Web3 realized with the Ceramic team and community.

Ceramic is led by @somemikesena, @dazuck and a team of exceptional individuals. With this latest funding, the team is looking to accelerate hiring across engineering, product, and community. See their career page for more: https://t.co/wXwvWHgCiK

As an example, @rabbithole_gg uses Ceramic to create an aggregate reputation linked to a user‚Äôs multiple wallets and accounts. Rabbithole then issues and stores this reputation score as a verifiable credential that can be consumed by any application.

Ceramic has realized a solution in a comprehensive way. Its network and tools form the basis for a data layer that enables a ton of interesting use cases for data composability: from structured NFT metadata, to decentralized identity, user profiles, Web3 social graphs and more.

Imagine a "pingback" protocol that updates the metadata with each re-use of the NFT in a new context. This could enable others to get notified that an NFT was added to someone‚Äôs Twitter profile, or hung in someone‚Äôs Oncyber gallery.  https://t.co/dthmIKAMWb
In Ceramic, NFT metadata canbe remixed or extended, for example, to include a rich history of all interactions with the work...

Tracking attribution of media using blockchains is now  popular: NFTs -- but much of the important metadata about these assets still lives off-chain as data blobs on centralized servers or networks like IPFS where they‚Äôre difficult to consume, remix and extend.

I‚Äôve been drawn to the vision of creating a decentralized data infrastructure for Web3 since before ‚ÄúWeb3‚Äù as a term existed. At Mediachain, we built a decentralized data layer for structured media metadata, to track attribution for who made or owned an image, video or song.

Since launching its beta in June of 2021, Ceramic has been used by thousands of developers, and more than 400 applications have collaborated on shared data via its network. We‚Äôre excited to see this growth continue as it enters open mainnet.

Ceramic is a decentralized data network that makes data composable across applications. 

If networks like @ArweaveTeam are Web3's hard drive, @ceramicnetwork is its database, where you read/write/query structured data for applications.

Pumped to share that @variantfund invested in @ceramicnetwork ‚Äòs $30M Series A. 

If DeFi is money legos, and NFT are media legos, Ceramic enables data legos.

Innovating on transportation is going to be key in the fight against climate change, and one of the reasons I'm excited about DIMO is that it makes innovation permissionless by leveraging vehicle data provided by individuals, rather than companies.
2,500 DIMO-enabled Data Miners have been pre ordered through https://t.co/hvI1g3XStS, and the first units have already been delivered and installed in consumer vehicles.
Since launching https://t.co/F5YCnnroch in December, over 17,000 vehicles have been added, with demand from over 700 fleets, and dozens of mobility service companies building on the platform.

Users can create an account using a mobile or browser interface that connects the car to DIMO‚Äôs network using either the built-in vehicle software or a hardware device produced by DIMO and Autopi, called a miner.

DIMO‚Äôs marketplace allows developers to build applications that consume these driver-provided data. 

Relevant use cases include battery optimization for electric vehicles, insurance, vehicle sharing, financing, and utility grid management.

DIMO is building a user-owned IoT platform that allows drivers to collect and share vehicle data, earning ownership in the platform's marketplace for their contributions.

If you like Helium and have a car, you'll like @DIMO_Network.

My gut is the most interesting projects built in Web3 will have fluid, delegated governance‚Äîbecause interestingness derives from adaptability, evolution, surprise.
 
Fortunately in Web3, updating governance is just software‚Äîso the design space is open to whatever we can dream up

And one more angle on answering that question:
 
https://t.co/Dubu1hd16B

There are tons of experiments running to define best practices, and new tooling to boot (see @boardroom_info, @coordinape, @SyndicateDAO, @viamirror, et al) 

https://t.co/GxedOw4atG

DAOs can thwart hostile delegates with governance mechanisms that give token holders ample recourse if decisions diverge from their interests.
 
For example: forced delays/vetos before changes take effect. And as a last resort, there's always forking.

Given the ethos of decentralization that Web3 spawned from, delegation can be controversial. But it doesn't need to be.
 
In my eyes, delegation is compatible with decentralization, so long as leadership and governance design is representative of a decentralized stakeholder base

But OSS culture and smart contracts don't alter scarce human attention, which is the key ingredient in smart decision making.
 
To scale human attention and decision making, you need to delegate it.

Of course DAOs are different from corporations and co-ops in that anyone in the world can participate, governance processes can be much more transparent, efficient, and fluid due to open source culture and smart contracts.
Unlike corporations, management in these types of member-owned orgs answer to the interests of stakeholders, who are different from shareholders focused on the maximization of profits.

DAOs superpower is fluid, hierarchical leadership.

"Commoditize the compliment" is a concept with long roots in tech strategy.

Web3's ownership economy provides us with new tools to execute it, to grow networks to become bigger, and more valuable than their predecessors.

Here's the pocket playbook from the post: https://t.co/9cCfboKq20

This is warranted, but ultimately, protocol treasuries would be wise to optimize for multiple teams incentivized similarly, to grow the pie bigger, faster. 

Grants and meritocratic developer mining programs are ways of achieving this, but we need more sophisticated work on this.

3/ Often, the initial protocol/product duo that helped to bootstrap network effects in a Web3 platform is rightfully rewarded for their outsized contribution to the ecosystem with an allocation of tokens...

2/ Both product and protocol teams should be aligned around a shared KPI: protocol growth. 

Measuring against a shared protocol-level metric helps ensure the product is truly complementary, and can be an anchor for meritocratic distribution of value-driven.

The product team learns what end-users need, and can help inform the protocol design. And as the protocol team learns what product devs require, they can consider adding features that will attract more of them.

1/ As a Web3 platform matures, there may be a benefit to structuring the core project development work between two teams: those focused on the underlying platform or protocol, and those building the initial product for the end-user.
Wrapping up, some üí≠ for builders looking to execute the Web3 version of "commoditize the compliment:"

Some early examples include grants programs from large DeFi protocols, like @uniswapgrants  and @compoundgrants, or developer rewards from L1/L2 protocols.

@LiquityProtocol rewards devs who build front-ends to for their stablecoin with $LQTY pro-rata based on user deposits.

The Web3 model of commoditizing the complement demands a structural distinction between protocol from product, with an economic equilibrium that symbiotically links them together.

There's lots of optimization work to do here.

This is how Web3 projects can commoditize the complement, not as a means of draining profits and position from a potential competitor, but as a practical means of furthering sustainable co-opatition between product teams.

This practice of progressive decentralization aligns incentives around growing value in the underlying protocol, putting teams that earn tokens for their contribution in a better position to commoditize their own products and drive further growth.

These network effects helped attract third-party developers (e.g. @rainbowdotme) who built more functionality, attracting more users and usage. 

Next, a distribution of ownership in the form of tokens was aimed at those driving the value: users and developers.
Making Uniswap Protocol's early DeFi innovation accessible via an intuitive, user-friendly front-end, at zero-cost, was critical to bootstrapping liquidity network effects.

Lets take Uniswap as an example:

Uniswap Labs, the company, built https://t.co/IrM9wf2NW9, the first interface to the Uniswap Protocol on Ethereum (can't be stopped.)

Web3 teams building protocols are often first to build a product on top, and then...give it away for free. 

Like Web2, this helps bootstrap users, liquidity/data, and network effects of the underlying protocol. 

But in Web3, they won't stop.

Web3 projects have an opportunity to do things differently, owing to the fact that they can distribute tokens to turn their users into owners, empowering them to govern the platform in alignment with their continued interests.

Then they had to extract profits, so they stopped.  

Shifting their APIs from commodities to walled-gardens put them in zero-sum conflict with devs and the users who benefited from their creativity.

3/ Web2 social media platforms ran powerful, temporary versions of the strategy early in their growth phase:

By giving away their API, they commoditized their platform, attracting an ecosystem of developers who built businesses on top.

2/ Google open-sourcing TensorFlow, their powerful machine learning engine.

Commoditizing the engine killed would-be startup competitors, got devs using and improving their software, and drove demand for the enterprise version/compute on Google Cloud.

1/ $MSFT lowering the cost and increasing the addressable market for PCs:

By granting licenses of Windows to any manufacturer who'd pay, they fostered fierce competition in hardware, drove down PC prices, and increased their distribution > demand > pricing power‚ôªÔ∏è
Some notable examples in tech history to illustrate how "commoditizing the compliment"works and why the ownership economy of Web3 is additive:

Cereal/milk
Printers/ink
Gas/cars

The core idea of commoditizing the compliment:

The lower the price of your product's compliments, the more useful your product, the more demand and value to capture.

OP: https://t.co/unG3GMIsFU

~20 years ago, @spolsky coined a phrase describing one of the most impactful strategies of startups and tech giants:

"Commoditize the compliment"

This strategy is looking even more potent in Web3

In summary

LFG

All of this can be direct-to-fan artist monetization, which is what I set out to build with @coolmanagers back in the day. 

Now we have the tools to do it, where artist attribution and monetization can happen independent of any label or single platform.

With a burgeoning market for 1/1 song NFTs, the mental models are laid to expand the wedge to adjacent opportunities:

By way of analogy:

- 1/1 Song NFTs: "the master"
- Editions: vinyl/merch/fan club membership
- Series: collectible by association (a rare label release)

Collecting 1/1 song NFTs isn't a game only elite collectors can play...

An artist with even 100 true fans can sell song to those 100 fans collectively via @KoopXYZ or @prtyDAO.

Song NFTs are likely to succeed at reframing music as collectible art objects.

Contrast that with songs as free commodities on Spotify, and its clear...

Song-NFTs flippen song-copyright as *the* canonical representation‚Äîthe one you want to own because it has more market value.

NFTs thrive on reflexive markets. 

Imagine the Bloomberg headline on how much they paid for the Kanye song as an NFT (think Beeple)

That headline only begets more artist and developer interest =>  market development => more supply => demand (?) => higher prices (?)

‚ôªÔ∏è

Music is the most criminally undervalued and under monetized media-type relative to its consumption. 

I am increasingly convinced that 1-of-1 song NFTs are the wedge that will catalyze a dramatic shift in how artists make money and fans value music.

Music NFTs are where digital art was in 2020:

About to redefine the value and (100x) the business model of the medium forever. üßµ

To pull this future forward, we believe it takes a new kind of investor ‚Äî one that is crypto-native, but also has deep empathy for mainstream users.
 
That is why I am thrilled to announce that my friend @ljin18 is merging @AtelierVentures and becoming GP at @variantfund.

Beyond the positive social outcomes of more widely distributing assets that can help people build wealth, we believe that alining users with the success of products they use is also the most optimal way to scale software services and communities.
Variant's founding mission is to build a more equitable internet. Success for us is a world in which everyone becomes an owner of the products and services that they use.

@blitmap is one of the healthiest creative communities in Web3, whose users are anchored around ownership of NFTs created by artists and remixed by community members. We like the blitmaps.

Aligned incentives.

Silicon Valley has known for years that to get the best talent to work for your company you've got to give ownership (in the form of stock options)

Crypto tokens move ownership at the speed of information‚Äîto a global market of talent aligned w growth.

To me, a network qualifies as Web3 if the cashflows and ownership structure is controlled "on-chain" ‚Äî meaning its controlled by software written by developers and running on a public blockchain (as opposed to legal contracts written and run by lawyers)

#beyondweb3

Ownership.

In Web2, networks are owned by a select group of people who invest or work for the company.

In Web 3, the opportunity is to build networks owned by those that contribute‚Äîbe it with code, machines, content or community building. 

The users own the networks.

Many Web3 marketplaces are *user-owned*, which means they don't need to maximize profits for shareholders. Instead, they can maximize benefits to users by being minimally extractive (or operating at cost)

More on this here: https://t.co/a065b7ewsF

Web3 media rebundling will be via DAOs (community-owned internet organizations) that provide new distribution channels, funding, web3-native services, and premium monetization to creators.

Think of it as a Web3 CAA or Art Gallery.

https://t.co/TFjH2k5f77

In Web3, NFTs are unbundling monetization from distribution.

Creators can now monetize directly, independent of distribution platform.

But running an independent biz is hard, especially when the field is noisy and you need to stand out to capture top dollar.

Media is a pendulum:

Bundling and Unbundling

Web2: 

Social unbundled media cos into independent creators + distribution/monetization platforms. 

Now, TikTok Houses, Substack Collectives (eg @Every) are rebundling creator services with premium monetization.

right now none of these royalties flow on chain, so the winning bidder on this NFT will have to make arrangements with @jacquesgreene to figure that out.

platforms like Spotify have to pay publishing royalties when the play a song. 

so do arenas when the play songs at a basketball game.

its arcane to administer this.

publishing royalties are part of the legacy music copyright system. they are rights for use of the song *writing*, which is different the recording of that song.

(e.g. a song can be performed/recorded by multiple artists)

Love to see old friends experimenting on the bleeding edge.

This NFT includes publishing rights to the song. 

This is the idea that sparked my journey from music to crypto.

Soon all IP will be onchain, direct to creators, and we'll obviate copyright w something better.

To unpack this, I addressed a number of common Qs on NFTs:

I believe we are well on our way to NFTs becoming the "port of entry" for every piece of media on the internet because every stakeholder involved‚Äîcreators, their audiences, and developers‚Äîcan all make more money in a marketplace built around true digital ownership.

Meanwhile, crypto is unlocking a new model, where creators can own and capture the value of their work directly.

This a key tenet of The Ownership Economy‚Äîa broader thesis on what crypto tokens and smart contracts unlock:

https://t.co/pxKU2HEcdE
Thats because somewhere in the Terms of Service, it says that when a file is uploaded, its ownership is shared with the platform, to monetize as they see fit.
This may seem like a lightweight interaction, but when uploading, creators don‚Äôt simply copy a file‚Äîthey also copy-paste ownership of the file to the platform itself.

Today, billions of images, videos, songs, and more media will be shared on social media. 

When those files are posted, a copy of the media is taken from the creator‚Äôs device and pasted to the server of the platform distributing it‚ÄîFacebook, Twitter, YouTube, TikTok and the like.

So if you squint, you can see that NFTs have the potential to invert the ownership model of internet platforms.

Why?

The result?

It is now possible to own digital media asset in the same way that you can own a digital financial asset, like Bitcoin.

A simple way to think about NFTs are as files that live on the blockchain. 

This means that like Bitcoin, they can't be copy-pasted, edited, deleted, or otherwise manipulated.

This post strings together a bunch of disparate tweetstorms and thoughts I've had over the years. 

Quick summary:

Crypto will be the "port of entry" for all internet media.

Thanks to @BrianBrooksOCC for conversations that inspired this post and Jonathan Dotan, @ntnsndr, @ammori, @jchervinsky, @HughKarp, @djuricjel, @acameronhuff, @jasonsomensatto, @johndneufeld, Sam Zadeh, and the Blockchain Association for input.

This model will not be for everyone! It may not even work for most!

But for founders building in The Ownership Economy its an interesting thought experiment on how to continue to lead development, while simultaneously pursuing user ownership to build network effects.

Ownership is an experience, with lots of design space.

For consumers, some form of KYC may be fine (its the status quo for most platforms)

And perhaps illiquidity is a feature, or at very least, tolerable in exchange for premium utility & long-term incentive alignment.

5/ Provide consistent disclosure of project information

The most important factor in the Schaden Test, which is employed by courts when considering the ‚Äúefforts of others‚Äù is access to information. The more accessible, the better the arg that the instrument isnt a security.

4/ Rely on financial contributions from members...

Cooperatives generally cannot sell equity in their organizations but they can raise through member contributions, and other means.

3/ Allocate earnings on the basis of patronage/contribution

Many networks already allow for a variation of this principle by, for instance, allowing tokenholders to be compensated by lending or staking their tokens, or for developer contributions.

2/ Limit token transfer and focus on utility, not price.

Incidental appreciation is OK, but there should be no expectation of profit.

It might help to limit tokens transfers to other members who intended to *use* the service, e.g. @NexusMutual's whitelisted AMM exchange.

So what are key characteristics/tradeoffs co-ops make that crypto might consider?

1/ Democratized decision making

This means token-holders having *equal* votes in selecting leadership or making decisions about protocol upgrades. 1 person, 1 vote‚Äîso yes, KYC.

Many networks unknowingly share similarities that might allow for the argument that, like cooperatives, user ownership is not to be mistaken for a security.

For those willing to make tradeoffs that optimize for strong leadership, this elective could be a viable path.

So how can founding teams stay involved, and continue to steward the overarching goals of a great user experience and consumer protection?

Build *like* a co-op‚Äînot literally incorporated as such, but functionally equivalent.

This offers an opportunity to decentralize decision making, while providing an open source tool to the community.

That said, when a founding team steps away, users risk the loss of their institutional knowledge and efficient leadership. 

Flat decision making can slow progress.

So first, the problem:

Many crypto startups have successfully made their users into owners via Progressive Decentralization.

But many founding teams feel compelled to step back from their projects once a token is live, to reduce risk that it will be deemed a security.

IANAL and this post does not provide a comprehensive legal analysis.

We are flagging this argument for further consideration in the hopes that crypto teams will consider them with their own counsel :)

On governance participation:

- Continuous (MKR) vs. Discrete (UNI/COMP)
- Mandatory (YFI) vs. Optional 
- High Quorom (UNI) vs. Low (AAVE)
- Foundation vs. On-Chain

On users engagement:

- # Uniques
- Median Capital Balance/Gini Coefficient
- CAC vs. LTV (h/t @dberenzon)
- Liquid vs. Vesting/LockedUp
- Dividend vs. Burn vs. Pure Governance?
- Flat vs. Delegate Governance

On tokens issuance:

- Distribution speed: fast (YFI) vs. slow (COMP)
- Decelerating vs. Linear vs. Accelerating
- Retroactive vs. continuous
- Reward based vs. sold
So what trade-offs and metrics are interesting to measure when considering the effectiveness of ownership distribution?

Together with @eddylazzarin I put together a list of tradeoffs to measure against. 

The plan is to back out data driven insights to help builders make better choices!

To help accelerate this, we need a data driven approach to measuring whats worked and what hasn't. 

KPIs to measure against.

And from that, we can back out best practices that may be repeatable across projects, further accelerating iteration.

Each time an app runs an ownership distribution program‚Äîwhether via ICO, liquidity mining, or treasury governance program‚Äîthere is data to learn from and iterate on. 

These learnings are happening faster and faster.

In DeFi and other crypto apps, the objectives that mechanisms are designed to reward are far more complex, the stakeholders more diverse, and the type type of work being done more subjective‚Äîmaking it difficult to verify.

Mechanism design assumes rational behavior, and is easiest to reason about when the designed-for objective can be verified deterministically.

Miner rewards in BTC & ETH are an example of mechanism design for verifiable work: PoW + transaction ordering.

Taking a step back, figuring out ownership distribution is an exercise in Mechanism Design: 

"a field in economics and game theory that takes an objectives-first approach to designing economic mechanisms or incentives, toward desired objectives..."

https://t.co/V5EsPlarqL

In crypto, user-ownership can help drive network growth faster than any Web 2 growth hacking tricks

But nailing an effective ownership distribution is one the biggest challenges (and opportunities) for teams.

Best practices remain murky. 

Can we fix that? Thread üëá

I'm going to start pinging some folks I'd love to see more of in Ownership Economy platform governance, particularly in DeFi ... stay tuned.
As I started by saying, @VariantFund is looking to delegate its stake in community-owned networks to delegates today.

Probably many more DOs and DONTs to add. 

Feel free to jump in with more. 

I'll compile and put together a blog post to live on beyond Twitter.

DON'T abuse delegate power to advance your own personal interests.

Life is long. It'll catch up with ya.

DON'T commit indefinitely. 

Be clear about how much time you can commit, and when you'll reconsider being a delegate.

What DON'T you need to do as a delegate?

DON'T feel obliged to over-extend yourself. Do the work you're comfortable contributing, and again, ask for support where you need it.

Finally, DO ask for support.

Governance is work. 

Its why management teams of corporations (and succesfull co-ops!) get paid big bucks.

Solid Ownership Economy governance will reward contributions meritocratically. Propose it!

What can platform owners expect from you as a delegate? 

For example, will you...

- Be part time or FT? 
- Need compensation?
- Publish a rationale on decisions before/after voting? 
- Submit execution code?
- Provide initial proposals on XY or Z?

Why did you decide to become a delegate?

For example, you...

- want to represent underrepresented interests in the user/developer community

- bring a new perspective to the table

- are building a project that depends on the continued success of the platform youre governing
Consider sharing the following info with your announcement ‚Äî so token holders know where you're coming from:

Include a delegate address in your announcement, so token holders know where to delegate to.

If the platform is based on Ethereum, thats just an Ethereum address you want associated with your identity and reputation.

Once you've browsed some topics and decided you want to get involved‚Äîhow DO you actually execute on it?

First, signal your intent to be a delegate publicly.

Announce that you‚Äôd like to serve as delegate (e.g. on Twitter + https://t.co/k3yIT2DChX)
Your opinion counts, and the more you express it and engage with others, the more credibility you'll build as a voice for community members to get behind.

So HOW do you get involved?

To start, monitor and participate in topics that interest you. 

For example, track topics directly on governance dashboards like https://t.co/ss03bdTbiD or across projects aggregators like https://t.co/geDi5lyQvs

First, what does it take to be a delegate?

A: Whatever you have to give. 

Value add in governance comes in different shapes and sizes: full-time, part-time, developers, users, marketers.

If you have an opinion, you can get involved.

Ownership Economy platforms (e.g. @UniswapProtocol, @CompoundFinance) benefit from independent delegates representing users in governance.

@VariantFund wants to delegate to user reps (esp in DeFi) today.

Thinking about getting involved? 

Wrote a list of delegate DOs & DONTs üëá

Just as tokens and smart contracts are "money legos" for developers to permissionlessly compose and remix.

NFTs will be "media legos" for developers to build the next Spotify or Netflix on top of a programmable library of content that preserves attribution/value for creators

A canonical ID+metadata is exactly what an NFT is.

As more work gets tokenized, we'll get closer to achieve the original goal of Mediachain: a "universal media library"

That metadata could be who made it, what its about, its history online, its licensing terms. 

Developers could consume that info to build more expressive and rich media experiences that enable more value‚Äîboth financial and contextual to flow to creators and consumers alike.

I often say that many of the goals of my last startup (@mediachain_) are being realized through NFTs. 

Internally, we referred to Mediachain as a ‚Äòcanonical content registry‚Äô where every unique work would get a canonical ID that you could append metadata to

DeFi : Money Legos
NFTs : Media Legos

What will be the biggest lessons learned from the yield farming wave üåä?

It‚Äôs the cycle of speculation ‚ôªÔ∏è 

Genuine new model emerges, speculators/bad actors rush, then second movers optimize and productize.

This is exactly how successful DeFi projects emerged from the wake of the 2017 ICOs; the lesson was build a product + progressively decentralize

The good news is there‚Äôll be an opportunity for second movers to learn from the mistakes of the first generation of yield farming, and design more optimal distributions to balance liquidity growth with community growth and contribution over time.

Im sure DeFi has lots of room to grow, but in many cases, the growth is tumorous.

Short term speculators are in and out, and will leave many of these projects‚Äîwho aim to be community owned and operated‚Äîas ghost towns, much like 2017 ICO projects.

Crypto exposed the power of ownership as a way to drive users to contribute to new protocols in deeper ways.
 
Now, the opportunity is to build more accessible products (and protocols) that bootstrap adoption & participation through better economic alignment with users.

Software ate the world.
 
So its no surprise that narratives around economic empowerment online are resonating more than ever.
 
And as the barriers to professional connectivity have fallen dramatically, so too have the hurdles for more equitable distribution of economic value.

Platforms like @BirdRide and @DumplingUS combine the scale of software-driven marketplaces with equity value accrual for supply-side operators by allowing suppliers to run franchises that they truly own.

In consumer, upstart house-of-brands, Arfa, is rewarding customers who contribute to product development with a 5 percent share of company profits.
 
They hope direct economic incentives can help build a more loyal customer base with lower marketing costs over time.

Consumer marketplace @withFND is transforming the Kickstarter model by allowing creators to tokenize  projects.
 
Tokens can be bought, sold or redeemed, and this form of programmable, digital ownership unlocks new revenue streams from resale for creators & buyers alike.

In social, @reddit recently announced they will reward valuable subreddit contributors with community currencies, the value of which derives from paid membership, tipping, and badges.
 
More here: https://t.co/9oadGRKkXZ

@CompoundFinance, a P2P money market, recently completed its journey of progressive decentralization to become a community-owned marketplace for borrowing and lending.
 
More here: https://t.co/0x4lp470P2
In finance, startups like @Binance and @Numerai have their own tokens to distribute revenue from the platform directly to their users, fueling brand loyalty and growth.

Some Examples:
 
In payments, @CeloOrg is making digital dollars accessible to anyone with an internet connection via a blockchain that, like Ethereum, is entirely user owned and operated.

Ownership doesn't always mean a literal distribution of tokens or equity. It also doesn‚Äôt mean an app needs to be entirely built on a blockchain.
 
Rather, ownership can be a keystone of new user experiences, with plenty of design space to explore.

The early BTC & ETH communities were technologists and devs, among the first to recognize tokens as a powerful ownership incentive.
 
But now, user ownership is crossing the chasm.
 
The Ownership Economy is playing out in dev infra, fintech, marketplaces, social, and more: https://t.co/vJvQkYkR8X

This technology breakthrough highlighted a new model for networks that are entirely built, operated, and *owned* by users who contribute.
 
This idea ‚Äî user ownership ‚Äî is at the core of the success of Bitcoin and Ethereum, the first community owned and operated networks at scale

Crypto tokens are the latest protocol innovation to expose a disruptive new model.
 
Just as BitTorrent allowed us to exchange packets of information instantly and without an intermediary, crypto tokens let us distribute value in the same way.

One person who saw an opportunity was @eldsjal, founder of Spotify.
 
As CEO of ¬µTorrent, one of the most popular BitTorrent clients, Ek understood that piracy wasn‚Äôt about stealing‚Äîit was about access.
 
So they delivered a clean UX around the experience of "every song ever."

A good example is BitTorrent, the protocol innovation that underpinned the streaming revolution.
 
While Netflix was mailing DVDs, the breakthrough peer-to-peer technology allowed consumers to access media in real time.
 
By 2004, it comprised one-third of all internet traffic.

Protocol ‚Üí Product innovation cycles fit a pattern:
 
First, early-adopters use new protocols to do things that were impossible before the technology breakthrough enabled it.
 
Then, a winning formula for founders is to build products that make the new model more accessible.

While most prevalent in crypto today, The Ownership Economy is expanding into other areas in tech.
 
To understand why, we can look to recent history and observe how protocol innovations often expose disruptive new models that, when productized, can go on to impact billions.

Beyond being a positive social endeavor, this more cooperative model taps into one of the strongest market incentives to build adoption & network effects.
 
The result is platforms that can grow larger and be more resilient and innovative over time.

Now, new technologies are shifting the future of work and distribution of ownership value to internet-native models.
 
From developer to consumer facing platforms, ownership is becoming a new tool for bootstrapping products that are increasingly operated by their users.

Ownership has been a powerful tool for incentivizing talented people to dedicate their skills to building startups in Silicon Valley.
 
While this model has been incredibly successful, it hasn‚Äôt been accessible to all.

One of the most remarkable things about the technology we use everyday is the degree to which it is built, operated and even funded by its users.
 
Think of open source software, user-generated content, marketplaces, crowdfunding.
 
The Ownership Economy is what comes next.

@VariantFund is early-stage venture capital for crypto networks and founders building The Ownership Economy.

What other questions are you thinking about?

Would be fun to note whether you are a $COMP user or dev ‚Äî or if you‚Äôre considering becoming one now (b/c of community ownership?)

Will the protocol remain minimally extractive?

Back on neutrality and sustainability, what is the optimal margin to extract in order to build, operate, and deliver the most beneficial service, as defined by $COMP token holders?

How will the community support ongoing operations?

Who will pay for the work of governing, improving and growing the service? 

What is the optimal allocation for each of these efforts respectively?

How will community decision making scale? 

Will all token holders vote, or will delegation prove a more effective way to scale organizational efficiency? Some mix of both?

This will be fascinating to watch.

Is the distribution widely representative of the user base, ensuring governance of the marketplace remains neutral & aligned?

This is important because neutrality can inspire confidence, especially among developers who build on top and make the protocol more valuable.

Is the chosen distribution of ownership effective?

That is, does the token incentivize contribution to the protocol in the right ways, at the right time? 

Right now, the design incentivizes increased usage & growth. How much do users value ownership? How will we measure this?

One of the most important experiments in crypto to date: 

The handoff of ownership & control over a complex and valuable marketplace to its community of users 

There will be a lot to learn from participating. Some open Qs for the communityüëá

A complementary read is @ystrickler's recent book "This Could Be Our Future" which details how the narrative of "Financial Maximization" took hold and has accelerated since the 1970s. 

He also offers a framework for building new economic narratives to improve our future.

There are many more variables, and tons of good examples in the book. 

My takeaway is that predicting economic events can depend heavily on the epidemiology narratives. Viral stories matter. Duh.

Scale is also a variable. 

Major economic events can be tipped by small ripples in popular discourse, each of which form a constellation of intertwined narratives that make waves over time.

Bitcoin is a good example of the constellation effect.

In general, economic narratives have a number of variables that determine their success and impact:

Speed is one. Narratives can permeate culture and impact economies quickly or slowly, but what matters is the rate of contagion vs. the rate of recovery (debunking the narrative)

One other that I'll add is the narrative around fixed supply: the sacred 21M.

The fixed supply narrative is reinforced by the "money printer go brrrr" narrative.

And also by the recurring halvening (the pre-scheduled decrease in the supply that can be mined into circulation)

Then there is the narrative of BTC as membership in a global, autonomous economy, free of the perennial problems of  government incompetence and corruption.

Both technically and psychologically, Bitcoin offers an escape hatch from increasing distrust in traditional institutions.

With Bitcoin, anyone could participate in cutting edge wealth creation, even if you don't understand how it works.

Remember the guy who sold a pizza for BTC who's now a billionaire?

Participation by Regular Joes multiplies the repetition of glory stories on the cutting edge.

Then came the stories of how investors got rich simply by being on the cutting edge of "what's next."

This is the lure of VC and startups in general, and it is reinforced by repetition of founder and early investor glory stories.

This dovetailed with "software eating the world" or the story of computers playing a greater role in people's lives

Bitcoin offers a way to benefit from the rise of computers‚Äî to participate in history, even if only superficially (without having to master computer science.)

This made Bitcoin's early narrative not only anti-establishment, but also intertwined with individual economic empowerment.

Outsiders benefited from BTC's first major price gains in 2011, a time when economic inequality advanced rapidly & the Occupy Movement was birthed.

Satoshi's very first transaction on the Bitcoin blockchain embedded the London Times headline: 

"Chancellor on brink of second bailout for banks" 

This signaled about the risks of governmental abuse of  power to reward the rich and powerful.
Bitcoin's affiliation with anarchy is intertwined with a human interest story about its pseudonymous creator, Satoshi Nakamoto, who remained cloaked to avoid scrutiny by world governments.

What are the Bitcoin narratives?

A constellation of stories about:

- Anarchist sentiment & human interest (Satoshi)
- Individual economic empowerment
- Software eating the world (@pmarca) 
- Getting rich on the cutting edge
- Membership in an autonomous economy

Lets unpack...
The books gives many examples of economic narratives, but one I think is particularly well documented and interesting is the constellation of narratives in #Bitcoin .

What is an economic narrative?

- a contagious story that affects economic decision making
- spreads virally p2p
- often aided by celebrity/human interest and/or recursion
- reminds people of facts they might've forgotten
- offers an explanation about how the economy/world works

Narrative Economics is the study of the viral spread of popular narratives that affect economic behavior. 

The book explores historical examples of how stories go viral, referencing epidemiology to explain why contagious narratives can become epidemics and move markets.

Here is my high level reading/summary of 
@RobertJShiller‚Äôs book: "Narrative Economics"

Membership vs Transaction Fees is a cognitive load tradeoff space.

@julien51 Same with Web 2.0 marketplaces. It‚Äôs all about liquidity :)

@julien51 It may only make sense to turn fees on once network effects are strong enough to support them. 

So long as switching costs are higher than the fee, the friction will be worth it.

Distributing a fee stream to users via tokens entrenches network effects, generates more defensibility and further warrants the exsistence of a fee.

It is a virtuous cycle that allows for sustainable, community owned networks.

Fees only make sense if you‚Äôve got enough defensibility to charge them and still win.

In each of the dAPI examples given there are network effects at play.

Network effects create switching costs, which in turn, create an opportunity to extract a margin by charging a fee.

Stripe or Twilio shares are valuable because they capture a fee stream.

Most crypto tokens will similarly be valuable because they are  backed by fees in a marketplace.

Whats new is that tokens can be distributed like packets, directly to users who make the service valuable.

Crypto has a traditional business model.
Whats new is who benefits from it.

Bittorrent: Streaming

The internet & blockchains make information and trust programmable, and available at our fingertips. 

If the result is that more of the world's debt gets instrumented as venture-style equity, the result might be more risk taking + innovation  + economic alignment in society.

For this reason, labels are more like like VCs than banks. 

They are partners with artists, which requires a good amount of market information and some faith (also information)

Like VCs, some are good partners. Others not so much.

In equity financing there is more alignment around risk/reward, and overall, less recourse for capital if things don't work out.

This requires more trust, which in turn requires more information.

One framework I learned from @cdixon on debt vs. equity is to contrast them by the information and trust required.

In debt financing, you need less information, because the terms of the deal are more direct: "pay me, or else I'll come for everything you've got."

A friend asked if record deals are more like debt or equity (banks or VCs)

They're actually kinda both.

- Debt in that artist advances are often recoupable
- Equity in that artists aren't on the hook to pay if a record fails
h/t @ManuAlzuru

I'm wondering what others think about this...

What should I tie $WHAT to?

Apart from time, others are tying tokens to other forms of physically scarcity:

- $SOCKS are dynamically priced, designer socks: https://t.co/oFkSjfGoMI

- $FAME is redeemable for shirts designed by a community-owned brand : https://t.co/M5kaulBVmK

On the demand side, #PatronageforProfit is arguably a new consumer behavior.

But then again, the largest crowdfunding events in history were ICOs. Treated favorably, they validated demand for capital ownership in internet products and services.

People too?

For artists and freelance creatives, it'd be a big behavior shift to offer public access to their time, brand, and pricing.

For others‚Äîcreators producing commodity work, or those used to measuring follower counts, likes, or digital good sales in public‚Äîits not a stretch.

Personal tokens are the opposite. They are:

- Publicly accessible 
- Terms/SOW for redemption specified in advance
- Price trades on an open market (+/-)

No doubt, there are big markets for on-demand creative services, e.g. Fiverr, which let creators offer preset a SOW with a price. 

But for many creatives, building brand value entails:

- being selective about clients
- crafting a mutual SOW
- negotiating price (privately)

My next idea was to make $WHAT redeemable for a custom music playlist, curated by yrs truly.

That sounded more fun, but as I thought about it, I realized my issue is I'm generally uneasy about selling time to perfect strangers on the internet
This is similar to @dApp_boi, who AFAIK, got the personal token movement started by creating $BOI ‚Äî a token redeemable for 1 hour of his  design services (at https://t.co/CKIM0ltB6Z)

I thought about it, but yall dont need to pay for that. I'm a VC. Plus, theres a glut of supply

Its called $WHAT, a personal token that is redeemable for... 

Well, I'm not sure yet.

If you want to figure it out, read on...

As there's more demand for a creator's token, price should increase. 

A patron who doesn't redeem can profit from that appreciation by selling a fraction of their tokens.

But is #PatronageforProfit a feature or bug? 
For whom?

Buying personal tokens is a bit like paying for a Substack newsletter, or backing a Kickstarter project. 

Value accrues to the creator, and can be used to fund the production of products or services. 

The key difference is access to upside (+downside), like an ISA.

If you're not as deep in crypto, you might've missed that headz are minting their own personal tokens.

Redeemable for access to the creator, personal tokens are adjacent to more mainstream tech trends like #PassionEconomy memberships & ISAs

Call it #PatronageforProfit ?

I'm not suggesting anyone should play this game, but the mechanism design is interesting!

If you want to read more, check out the paper here:

https://t.co/B5wZK6seTD

The game features a prize pool that‚Äôs tied to the expiration of a timer that lasts 12 hours after participants stop interacting with it .

If the timer reaches zero, the the slowly- accumulating prize pool is split equally among the last 100 to play.

It is a system designed to employ "humans to fulfill its own needs, goals and desires by paying them..."

 "A precursor to a self-sustaining Artificial Intelligence, autodecentric software takes the first steps necessary to secure its own existence through external interaction.‚Äù
Team JUST (the developers behind the project) call it an "an experiment in psychology and economics, one that is as much educational as it is entertaining."

Sidebar, but this history of https://t.co/FAkkqQNfYe homepage design is a good reference:

https://t.co/uMkrLscSmn

Dinwiddie Bonds and fiat stablecoins are examples of this. 

Its worth noting the most interesting examples tend to enable new *consumer* behavior and experiences, not enterprise or institutional adoption.

Still, the intermediate adoption phase is important as it mixes properties of the legacy form with the new:

https://t.co/ehkxA6nphu
Tokens have fundamentally different properties vs. traditional capital instruments, so new types of capital assets will, and have emerged ($BTC is only the first example)

These new forms emerged because the nature of data packets is fundamentally different than legacy instruments for distributing information (books, newspapers, television broadcasts)

The same is true of tokens, a new instrument for distributing capital.

Gateways are a trojan horse for new platforms, pushing exploration of their unique capabilities forward.

For example, https://t.co/FAkkqQNfYe started out transposing print to the WWW. Over time, the website became primary; rich media & real-time news were only possible online.

I'm excited to see more types of offline value tokenized.

@RadenJake @ljin18 1995: ‚ÄúHow can any of this matter unless the government creates legal and regulatory frameworks to allow ecommerce online? They‚Äôll all be using the National Science Foundation network without a license!‚Äù

Prior to 95, it was actually *illegal* to use the internet for ecommerce.

Developers and crypto enthusiasts are the first communities building internet-native bizs in this way, but I believe many more communities will follow suit. 

SaaS products that build on this new stack will be able to offer better economics, alignment and flexibility to founders.

This means we can now:

- ‚ÄúIncorporate‚Äù a business digitally and own it like we can own digital gold (BTC)
- Earn, save and spend together
- Reward contribution with micro-payments that grow community and loyalty 
- Integrate #DeFi for real-time payroll & borrowing

Smart Contract platforms like Ethereum are new stack to express rules of economic collaboration as code. 

Plus, they enable allow packets of value flow like packets of information...with very low marginal cost, to anyone, anywhere.

SaaS products can abstract some of these steps, but they're built on a legacy stack that passes high fees and platform risk on to us, the founders.

We won't own our business. We'll just share our revenue with the platform. And we'll build by their rules.

Now say you and I run a subreddit community and decide to start a business... Well, if we each live in different countries, it's complicated. 

Where to incorporate? Where to bank? How to split payments? Who do we hire to set this up? How much will it cost? How will we pay?

In place of PayPal's employment agreements, the rules for compensating the work done in the Bitcoin network is expressed in code. The payments are programatic. Talent is open to anyone on the internet, not just those who can fill a W-2 tax form.
But whereas PayPal is a US company with employees, Bitcoin was built by an internet community of passionate, capitalist cypherpunks that collectively own and operate the network.

First, it's helpful to first view existing crypto networks as the earliest examples of the new internet-native business stack in action. 

Consider the very rough analogy that Bitcoin provides a somewhat equivalent service to PayPal. They both store and xfer value from A to B.

Agree w @ljin18 that many any more communities will shift from big social to bespoke community platforms.

The coexistence of multiple blockchain architectures is a nuance that my original post didn't capture, so I updated it recently here:

https://t.co/LiFHJBU33y

For this reason, I believe it's likely that many "server" or application-specific blockchains will end up existing alongside, and interoperating with, robust "mainframe" blockchains.

Aragon noted they plan to build bridges to Ethereum, and chose Cosmos SDK because of EVM support

While more dApps are likely to make this transition, it won't make sense for all.

#DeFi apps for example, will continue to benefit from robust, pooled security and permissionless composability. Even with high tx fees, many use cases will prove cheaper than offchain alternatives.

Building a full-stack "server" solution is more work, but it's getting easier...

@Cosmos SDK & @Polkadotnetwork's  Substrate provide the dev kits; Node-SaaS like @BisonTrails & @_blockdaemon help spin-up a decentralized network of supply-side nodes.

The solution in "server" blockchains is a custom-built, app-specific blockchain that doesn't compete for resources with other apps. 

At the moment, these architectures forego "composability" for bespoke support, akin to servers for Web 1 apps before cloud economies of scale.

"Mainframe" blockchains are general & timeshared in that multiple users/apps compete for limited resources... 

The marginal cost per user increases and eventually exceeds the marginal benefit of "composability" (sharing resources btwn apps in the ecosystem.)

Hopefully I‚Äôm missing something!
Multiplying instances of contracts across shards (e.g. one Maker contract per shard) fractures liquidity and kills network effects, so that‚Äôs not ideal!

Pruning state may make yanking efficient, but this too seems problematic, since shared, open state is what makes composability possible and exciting. 

It‚Äôs the best of stateful APIs, with the trust of open source code.

> For yanking to be efficient, the yankee‚Äôs internal state must be small so that it can be encoded in a receipt, and the gas cost of yanking would need to be proportional to the yankee‚Äôs total size.

You could argue that each of these apps should be on the same shard, no yanking required.

But co-location = shard gentrification üôÉ

Then you‚Äôre back to the scaling challenges of a singleton VM like ETH1 

https://t.co/f4HKhaoEzJ

This seems problematic for apps like @compoundfinance, @MakerDAO, which are aggregated by @InstaDApp and @argentHQ. The latter will have many users interacting at the same time. 

How will they know which shard the contracts will be on if they‚Äôre getting yanked around?

> ‚Äúyanking‚Äù a contract that exists on shard A effectively means freezing its state on shard A, saving the state into a receipt, importing the contract to shard B...then using another receipt to send the contract back to shard A where it then continues its existence.
To perform this kind of atomic transaction, Marble would need to "yank" all of the smart contracts it calls onto the same shard ...

Apps that call a smart contract on another shard (and need to wait for a response to continue) would break. 

Marble, an example in my post, would be one of these broken use cases, or it‚Äôd be much more difficult to build. https://t.co/wqf9plfBlw

Ironically, I used the term ‚Äúyank‚Äù to describe what shouldn‚Äôt happen to developers and the building blocks they use to foster composability!

Thanks to my team at @a16z crypto for conversations that led to this PoV (@cdixon, @katie_haun @ali01, @apruden, @literature and especially @bhorowitz who lived the first wave of internet layer-caking first hand.)
For builders, consider what use cases your network/product handles uniquely well. How does it compose with the unique capabilities of other layers in the cake and how do you talk about that?

The development of more advanced/scalable technologies does not necessarily cannabalize the specialized use cases of preceding eras, but instead results in a complex, layered stack. The space on top of these discrete foundations is likely much bigger than we currently know.

And while none of this is to say that BTC or ETH have won their respective layers forever, it is possible to view them continuing to play a role in these specialties with only modest upgrades/maintenance (such as proposals for state bloat in ETH 1.x)
Following this, projects that we now think of as competitive may turn out to instead be complimentary and interoperable.

As most analogies, this one is imperfect, but a takeaway is that if you expect individual blockchains to scale comprehensively, it's very easy to miss the unique purpose that they specialize in, and how specialization can end up facilitating fit in the larger ecosystem.

Each of these architectures may end up serving different applications. Add layers for privacy, storage, L2 scalability, node-SaaS, custodians and wallets and you start to have a thick, composable layer cake akin to the way the internet protocol stack developed.

Application-specific, "server era" blockchains that roll their own networks (e.g. those building on Cosmos SDK) may also be distinct from "cloud" era networks like Dfinity, Near, Polkadot, ETH 2.0‚Äîthe latter taking a more top-down approach to security issued from a base chain.

Even with network congestion leading to high fees, or wait times on the order of minutes or hours, these applications beat the UX of going to a bank for a loan, proxy/shareholder voting, or incorporation/dissolution of an LLC.

DeFi and DAOs are Ethereum's emergent use cases. Both take advantage of its strengths as a battle-tested, slow, secure computer for token adjacent applications like crowdfunding, lending, digital "incorporation," voting, etc.

Well, just as Ethereum hasn't killed Bitcoin, scalable decentralized computation may not kill the leading "mainframe" era blockchain. Ethereum's utility today is not that of a world computer, but that of a *world accounting system*

The latter is an especially dangerous assumption, because it can easily lead to the view that next generation smart contract platforms are defacto Ethereum killers, simply because they offer more (scaled) computation.

Similarly, Ethereum's early narrative, "a world computer", initially led many to 1) think Ethereum could replace Bitcoin because of its programmability and 2) assess it on the dimension of whether it would scale to internet-wide computation.

Rewind. Pre 2014, Bitcoin was widely viewed as internet-wide payment rails. 

At that time, it was clear Bitcoin's throughput wouldn't support internet scale xfer. Wait around for an upgrade, and risk missing it tip into its current role as SoV (less need for scalability.)
Where this goes wrong, I think, is in positing a linear evolution and suggesting that each era cannibalizes the next on the dimension of scale and internal composability.

The original post labeled BTC a calculator (single purpose), ETH a generalized mainframe to be followed by more scalable, app-specific server era blockchains, and then a highly scalable, composable, decentralized "cloud"

ultimately the degree to which interesting apps execute business logic deterministically "on-chain" may end up being less important than building orgs that leverage the chain to coordinate ownership and representative decision-making authority.

incomplete contracts can't scale through automation, and voting on each decision is inefficient and vulnerable to attack. here, market driven delegation of decision making may be the most effective solution.

the decentralization fixation that sparked the crypto movement depends on complete contracts, but many of the most interesting projects being built on top of blockchain computers are incomplete and require ongoing subjective decision making.

yet "all but the simplest contracts are incomplete" -- that is, anything that can't be deterministically verified (or made objectively legible to machines) will require dynamic and subjective judgement when complexity emerges.

tl;dr‚Äîcontracts are simply decision logic, akin to computer programs. 

"complete contracts" are programs whose outputs can be deterministically verified. determinism enables automation, which is "socially scalable" and well suited to decentralization.

8/ On top of these community-owned computers, devs are writing software to enable less technical communities to follow suit, and build their own participatory organizations that can generate and distribute value directly‚Äîno corporation required.
https://t.co/S50sTUbFmT

7/ Developers are the first community to leverage these tools. 

Together, they've built the first community-owned and operated internet computers, aka blockchains. These computers are run by community participants who are rewarded directly with a stake in the platform.

6/ Crypto networks are different.

They are the missing tool in the kit for online communities to step beyond online *communication*, towards internet-native organizations and services that capture and distribute value directly in bits.

5/ in large-part, this is because startups are corporations: legal entities that belong to the world of atoms, not bits like the communities they enable. they're made of contracts, bank accounts, payroll processors, I-9s, and all manner of otherüèõ üí©!

4/ the will is clear, but what about the tools?

while internet communities have generated tons of value using new *communication* tools. there hasn't been an effective means to distribute that value directly to participants.

And for more on governance in crypto, check out our series of pods @a16z:

I'll update here with the most interesting new governance experiments in crypto. 

Please lmk if there's anything else I should check out and add!

@Kleros_io enables smart contracts to integrate with a decentralized court system that randomly elects jurors to adjudicate disputes. Since "all but the simplest contracts are incomplete" a protocol for dispute resolution feels like an under-discussed topic in crypto governance!

...really fun start, but the economic model needs some more work if we expect this list to remain accurate. 

and last but not least (for now)...

@HumanityDAO is community-curated list (TCR) designed to incentivize its members to maintain a registry of human identities. There are currently 480 ETH addresses mapped to humans in the registry, which might be used for authentication, credit scores, democratic voting...

In exchange for funds/work, ownership tokens are issued to members who can use them to vote.  If a member disagrees with an outcome, they can choose to exit and reclaim their pro-rata portion of pooled assets‚Äîexit is an elegant way to ensure representation in funding allocation!

@MolochDAO and @meta_cartel are simpler permissioned "guilds" whose membership is curated by existing members, based on social reputation. The purpose of both is to pool funds and vote on allocation towards improving Ethereum's infrastructure/dapp ecosystem respectively.

Rather than simply analyzing decisions a management team makes, maybe the financial titans of the future will be armies of analysts helping steer those decisions for the collective by betting on optimal outcomes!
I also like this novel mechanism for ensuring vote isn't swung against the prediction market at the last min: https://t.co/A6hGtr4OXa

predictors bet on whether a proposal will be passed by voters, based on the org values/rules. proposals w the highest pass/fail ratio are boosted in the voting queue + only require a relative majority to pass.

the aim is to keep voting both representative & efficient, at scale

The next level are project choosing to leave the legal system behind and use purely internet native methods of coordination:

@daostack is a toolkit for managing decentralized orgs. It leverages binary prediction markets to identify and boost proposals worthy of group attention.
https://t.co/nlGI60blzS

For example, can fiduciary law protect protocol users/members from "51% attacks"? Maybe! Many open question to do with jurisdictional reach on-chain, but this continues to be an interesting direction. 

https://t.co/GuBApwUnZD

These hybrid organizations, grounded in the legal jurisdictions of a host country, effectively export local legal frameworks globally.

One aim is to bring benefits of their host legal system on-chain while adding transparency, efficiency, auditability and programmability.

They created their operating agreement on @OpenLawOfficial, which is creating "smart" legal contracts w/ portions implemented on-chain. Notable here is a markup lang which is legal, human *&* machine readable. 

@Mattereum is another hybrid system for ownership of physical goods
@AragonProject is experimenting with a DAO/LLC hybrid that issues legal shares through tokens. The whole workflow is wild and worth a read: https://t.co/tXltCujTeD

@NexusMutual offers insurance to cover smart contracts against loss, bugs, etc. A historically dominant way for communities to share risk, mutuals are member owned/operated.

Nexus is a registered legal entity in the UK, but it's membership is orchestrated through tokens! https://t.co/OOImy7idwC

maybe the trade-off is worth it. slow and steady innovation at L1 gives predictability, which buys time for the right innovations to get absorbed.

reminds me of Vitalik's post, below:

naturally, nothing works forever. at some point, Ethereum will need to address state bloat and other issues just to keep operating as expected.

and in lieu of a formal governance system, making these changes will no doubt be more difficult. but is it an insurmountable problem?

during time(t)‚Äîthe time where the protocol continues to operate as expected‚Äîinnovation can continue at Layer 2, devs can build apps on top of pooled security & liquidity, and meanwhile, other platforms will run the experiments to de-risk new CS and governance innovations.

so, in the short term, could protocol ossification due to lack of formal governance be a good thing? 

theres an argument that so long as a platform retains base functionality, foregoing experimental governance in exchange for predictable operation is a reasonable trade-off

Answers to these Qs will dictate whether blockchain computers are the tool that unlock a new wave of innovation in stakeholder-driven enterprises, which Fink is suggesting CEOs start building today.

What second order effects do software/contract automation unlock for human governance processes? Which ingredients from legacy stakeholder enterprises are still necessary and applicable here (e.g. identity, mgmt hierarchy, arbitration, rule of law?)

OTOH, it's not yet clear what exactly smart contracts unlock for subjective human governance. Thus far, the ‚Äústrong‚Äù form of blockchain computing has been mostly limited to autonomous, deterministic or algorithmic governance processes, not subjective human ones.

Could smart contracts be the tool that help this trend to hit escape velocity? That is, will they eliminate the structural inefficiencies associated with starting up and managing stakeholder controlled enterprises? This is the belief underlying experiments in ‚ÄúDAOs‚Äù...

Debate the attribution, but crypto's trend towards platform cooperativism is pushing more mainstream: last year, Airbnb expressed interest in issuing stock options to hosts. Fink's letter, and the purported ethical values of millennial consumers therein are further indicators.

Crypto networks aim for an ownership-control structure that is analogous to cooperative enterprises, where stakeholders are generally the consumers or suppliers of the cooperative‚Äôs product or service. 

This is what is meant by the term "community owned and operated" networks.

One way to view crypto is as a new experiment in stakeholder primacy. On the extreme, it is a techno-populist response to an economy that isn't working for everyone (due to the extractive short-termism of shareholder primacy that BlackRock's CEO discussed in his letter) üëá
